greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Self-inverse permutation of natural numbers: a(n) = A064989(A030101(A003961(n))).
comment: Shift primes in the prime factorization of n one step towards larger primes (A003961), then reverse the binary representation of the resulting odd number (with A030101), which yields another (or same) odd number, then shift primes in the prime factorization of that second odd number one step back towards smaller primes (A064989).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..8191
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
formula: A000035(a(n)) = A000035(n). [This permutation preserves the parity of n.]
mathematica: f[n_] := Times @@ Power[Which[# == 1, 1, # == 2, 1, True, NextPrime[#, -1]] & /@ First@ #, Last@ #] &@ Transpose @FactorInteger@ n; g[n_] := FromDigits[Reverse@ IntegerDigits[n, 2], 2] 2^IntegerExponent[n, 2]; h[p_?PrimeQ] := h[p] = Prime[PrimePi@ p + 1]; h[1] = 1; h[n_] := h[n] = Times @@ (h[First@ #]^Last@ # &) /@ FactorInteger@ n; Table[f@ g@ h@ n, {n, 83}] (* A266402, after _Jean-François Alcover_ at A003961 and _Ivan Neretin_ at A057889 *)
program: A003961(n) = my(f = factor(n)); for (i=1, #f~, f[i, 1] = nextprime(f[i, 1]+1)); factorback(f); \\ Using code of _Michel Marcus_
A064989(n) = {my(f); f = factor(n); if((n>1 && f[1,1]==2), f[1,2] = 0); for (i=1, #f~, f[i,1] = precprime(f[i,1]-1)); factorback(f)};
xref: Cf. A265329, A266404 (other conjugates or similar sequences derived from A057889).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jan 02 2016
